posts.title: Fake News Predictor
posts.descriptionHTML: Fake News Predictor is a web application that uses Recurrent Neural Network to identify unreliable news articles.

posts.title: The Scaredy Plant
posts.descriptionHTML: The Scaredy Plant is an anti-social robot inspired by sensitive plants that displays fear when interacting with its environment. With 8 actuating leaves on a wheeled flower pot, the Scaredy Plant can shrink its leaves and run away from frightening stimuli like loud noises and human shadows.

posts.title: The Sliding Puzzle
posts.descriptionHTML: I created an interactive website to explain how the A* and IDA* algorithms can be applied to solve the 15-puzzle. The 15-puzzle is a sliding puzzle that consists of 15 numbered square tiles in random order in a 4 by 4 frame. The goal is to re-arrange the tiles into their correct orders.

posts.title: Neighborhood Map
posts.descriptionHTML: Neighborhood Map is a single page map application using React, the Google Maps API and the Foursquare API. The map displays 25 coffee shops nearby the Cambridge area in Boston, MA. Initially, the app will fetch coffee shop data from Foursquare and populate them on Google map with red markers. Users can click on the markers to view details of the coffee shops including name, address, and picture. Users can also filter the list of coffee shops by typing keywords into the search bar.

posts.title: My Reads
posts.descriptionHTML: Using React, I created a bookshelf app that allows users to select and categorize books they have read, are currently reading, or want to read. The project emphasizes using React to build web applications. In this app, the main page displays a list of "shelves" (i.e. categories), each of which contains a number of books. Each book has a control that lets you select the shelf for that book. When you select a different shelf, the book moves there.

posts.title: Restaurant Reviews
posts.descriptionHTML: For the Restaurant Reviews projects, I converted a static webpage to a mobile-ready web application. I also added a service worker to create a seamless offline experience for users.

posts.title: Art Visualizer
posts.descriptionHTML: The Art Visualizer is designed to be an easy and accessible way for artists to visualize their motion, and turn the process by which they make art into a new form of art in and of itself. All that is required for data collection is a smartphone with the MATLAB Mobile app installed, which accesses accelerometer and gyroscope data (built into almost all present-day smartphones), and sends that data to be mapped and analyzed in MATLAB. What we have here is a proof of concept for an Art Visualizer phone app, which could access accelerometer and gyroscope data and run the code weâ€™ve put together, directly from your phone!

posts.title: Frogger Game
posts.descriptionHTML:
Apply OOP in Javascript to create a classic arcade game: the Frogger. In this game, you have a Player and Enemies (Bugs). The goal of the player is to reach the water, without colliding into any one of the enemies.

This is one of the projects for the Udacity Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree Program.

posts.title: Matching Game
posts.descriptionHTML:
The game board consists of sixteen "cards" arranged in a grid. The deck is made up of eight different pairs of cards, each with different symbols on one side. The cards are arranged randomly on the grid with the symbol face down. The gameplay rules are very simple: flip over two hidden cards at a time to locate the ones that match!

This is one of the projects for the Udacity Front-End Web Developer Nanodegree Program.

posts.title: Project Gemini - Collaborative Building
posts.descriptionHTML:
In the Spring of 2018, our team pulled off our most ambitious project yet, a collaborative building interaction between our twin arms, Pollux and Castor, where any model built by a human could be built by the robotic arms in its life-size form.

In this project, I developed perception algorithms to utilize RGB and depth data from the Intel RealSense camera to recognize 3D structures. I also incorporated transformation algorithms to reposition a captured 3D model to a desired coordinate system.

posts.title: Robotic Arm Solves Sudoku
posts.descriptionHTML: We programmed a robotic arm to solve a 4x4 Sudoku puzzle by itself (ROS in Python). The robot can be stopped anytime by the user using a built-in command interface. This was one of the team projects in the Olin's Robotics Lab in the Fall semester of 2017.

posts.title: Robotic Arm Plays the Card Game Set
posts.descriptionHTML: In this project, we programmed a robotic arm to identify and pick up 3 cards that make a set (ROS in Python). This was one of the team projects in the Olin's Robotics Lab in the Fall semester of 2017.

posts.title: PID Controller for Drone to Track a Target
posts.descriptionHTML: I designed a PID controller that can be used for a drone to follow a ground target. This piece of software (ROS in Python) was successfully tested on our simulator and applied on the real drone. I made this for the Olin AERO - IARC team in which we're building a drone to compete in the International Aerial Robotics Competition.

posts.title: ODEINT(iana Jones) and the Raiders of the Lost Semicolon
posts.descriptionHTML: Inspired by the famous scene in the movie, Indiana Jones and the Raiders of the Lost Arc, we set about to discover the optimal slope needed to slide a mass from the top of a hill to the position of a hapless grave robber, while taking drag and friction into account.

posts.title: YHack 2017: Project Underground
posts.descriptionHTML: Our web app provides an easy way for everyone to share their projects with other people, a way for college students to inform themselves about what others are doing and what kinds of things they could try in the future.

posts.title: xkcd Bot for GroupMe
posts.descriptionHTML: I made a simple bot that fetches newest xkcd comics and feeds them to a GroupMe conversation. The project was built on NodeJs and deployed on Heroku.
